Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research- SusChEM: Graded Interpenetrating Polymer Membranes Based on Sustainable Materials for Selective Removal of Organics from Water

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1512225/1510475
Alcantar/Cardena-Valencia
U of S. Florida/SRI

The collaborative team proposes to develop and investigate the performance of membranes based on natural, sustainable materials to remove organic contaminants from water. The ultimate goal of this project is to create novel membranes based on materials that have the ability to attract water pollutants and are renewable, biodegradable, and can be obtained via sustainable agriculture. A high percentage of the network forming these novel membranes will come from natural sugars and waxes. These compounds will be extracted from cactus mucilage, the gooey part of cacti. The separation process will invoke a similar function that cactus plants use to transport water to survive in arid environments to mimic the separation process of pollutants from water.

The proposed work focuses on the application of fundamental research of sustainable and natural materials capable of removing harmful organic chemicals from water. Although poly dimethyl siloxane (PDMS) membranes are readily-used in organic separations due to their hydrophobic nature and permeability to gases and organics, separation of higher molecular weight organics-semi-VOCs and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs)-remains challenging due to slow time-constants and selectivity. This project will invoke biomimicry to comparatively evaluate the use of polysaccharides from mucilage to emulate nutrient pathways in cacti. The polysaccharides will be cross-linked in PDMS networks and also in cutin waxes (materials that form the cactus skin). Since cutin waxes are extremely hydrophobic, this work potentially could establish that PDMS membranes will be replaced for more sustainable materials, which will be of high impact in the field.

Students working on this project will be trained to apply creative engineering perspectives to solving chemical and industrial challenges in problems intrinsically related to environmental assessments and water quality. The inclusion of undergraduate students will be achieved via an undergraduate research exchange internship between USF and SRI. In addition, high school students will be exposed to this project; the PIs will develop a new chemical laboratory lesson plan for a local high school in St. Petersburg, Florida.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Myriad organic contaminants that significantly affect human health have been detected in both industrial and urban polluted waters. These contaminants include polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) and semi-volatile organic compounds (semi-VOCs) such as toluene, benzene, phenol, dichloromethane, naphthalene, anthracene, and acetone, which are used in the fabrication of fuels, hydrocarbon products, cosmetics, adhesives, synthetic plastics, dyes, pharmaceuticals, and in the manufacture of electronic devices. The efficient recovery and quantification of organic solvents from aqueous mixtures poses several challenges due to the low concentrations and similar boiling points of organic compound mixtures in water. These issues have encouraged the search for cost-effective separation technologies that are able to purify aqueous effluents.

The objective of this project was to investigate the performance of membranes based on common polymers and natural sustainable materials for the separation and recovery of common organics, such as VOCs and PAHs, in aqueous systems. The proposed material development built on demonstrated success by researchers at the University of South Florida (USF) in chemical synthesis and extraction of functional materials using mucilage from cacti for the removal of contaminants in drinking water (e.g., flocculants of suspended sediments and arsenic) and the dispersion of crude oils in marine waters. SRI International (SRI) applied its expertise in Membrane Introduction Mass Spectrometer (MIMS) technology and polymerization to support USF's investigations of membrane development and characterization.

We studied different configurations of commercial polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) membranes and PDMS membranes made in-house and developed a model to investigate different parameters that affect separation. Our team at SRI assembled a pervaporation (or separation) laboratory setup that included a cell that held the membranes in the sampling interface of a MIMS to analyze membrane separation efficiencies. We characterized the organics-water separation of several classes of chemicals that would traditionally be hard to separate, such as 1-propanol and isopropanol and acetone and benzyl alcohol. The results of testing with PDMS membranes and those made in-house showed that thinner membranes and higher fluid temperatures were associated with increases in separation efficiency. Changes to the morphologies or structures of the membrane were also explored. The model we developed based on the chemical transport through the membrane enables investigation of how the parameters affect the separation of contaminants in aqueous solutions.

This project enabled a successful collaboration between a university and a non-profit research institute (industry). Our results from this investigation support USF's efforts to develop polymer blends or gradient polymers using sustainable materials derived from cactus plants. A USF graduate student was exposed to a research-prototype instrument and multidisciplinary research and development teams at SRI.


Last Modified: 07/03/2019
Modified by: Robert T Short
